encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be futher explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character's status as majuscule or miniscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Elemental edition: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.

app.rdg: 25[Emblem 25]
Emblem 25
AE TITLE

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.

Damned if you do, damned if you don’t–this emblem asks the reader to imagine three seemingly unrelated creatures who must choose between equally hazardous options: the flying fish who faces predators whether leaping in the sky or diving beneath the waters; a wounded deer who can flee and bleed to death, or get caught when resting to conserve energy; and Charles I, who surrendered during the civil war to those in his native Scotland (who betrayed him) in order to evade English armies. Envisioning the king as akin to a quivering and bleeding deer connects him imagistically with Pulter’s dying daughter, Jane, in “Upon the Death of my Dear and Lovely Daughter” (Poem 10), thus showing the crossover between Pulter’s vocabularies for expressing political and personal elegy. Yet what at first seems a lesson in futility turns, in this emblem’s final four lines, to a discovery of consolation, since Charles’ death offers a paradoxical triumph: martyrdom allows for fame and duration beyond the individual life. Pulter concludes not by drawing out the implications of the Christian paradox of dying to live, but by schooling her readers to put their tribulations into a larger perspective: after all, life could always be worse, as her three examples demonstrate–and even that “worse” might be, unexpectedly, conjoined with the very best.

app.rdg: Behold this flying &ff;iſh with Shineing Wings
Behold: this flying fish, with shining wings,
When &ff;orth“orth” appears written over other letters; two imperfectly erased ascenders visible at end the Swelling Billows up Shee Springs
When forth the swelling billows up she springs“forth” here indicates moving onwards or forwards from the billows, or ocean waves.,
Thinking but all in vain to flie away
Thinking, but all in vain, to fly away,
To hungry Hawks, and Kites, becom’s a prey
To hungry hawks and kitesbirds of prey becomes a prey.
Then down into the deep Shee dives again
Then down into the deep she dives again;
But then her &ff;oes within the &ff;rothey Main
But then her foes within the frothy mainopen sea
Whales, Sharks, Boneetoſ lie, \ lie \ and Watch each hour
(Whales, sharks, bonitosmedium-sized, tuna-like fish) lie and watchkeep watch, as in await a time in which, as the next line explains, to devour the creature, each hour,
This helples, harmles, Creature to devour
This helpless, harmless creature to devour.
Let diſcontented Spirits come and See
Let discontented spirits come and see
This perfect Map of infilicity
This perfect mapa summary or epitome; an embodiment or incarnation of a quality of infelicityunhappiness; misfortune.
Soe have I Seen a Hart w:th Hounds opprest
So have I seen a harta male deer (here gendered female) with hounds oppressed,
An Arrow Sticking in her quivering Breast
An arrow sticking in her quivering breast;
If Shee goes on her guiltles blood still &ff;lows
If she goes on, her guiltless blood still flows;
If Shee stands Still Shee &ff;als amongst her foes
If she stands still, she falls amongst her foes.
S,oe have I known (oh Sad) the Best of Kings
So have I known (O, sad) the best of kingsCharles I
(Ay mee the thought of this such horrour brings
(Ay mean expression of anguish, the thought of this such horror brings
To my Sad Soul) his Princely Spirit poſed
To my sad soul), his princely spirit posed
In Strange Delem̄as every where incloſed
In strange dilemmas, everywhere enclosed
By his ,and Gods depreſſed Iſraell’s foes

By his and God’s depressed Israel’s foesGod’s chosen people, Israel, are here compared to the English, who are “depressed” (brought low or oppressed as well as dejected) by their “foes” in the civil wars of the 1640s.;
In this great Strait his native Side hee choſe

In this great straitdilemma or difficult choice; confined place; time of need or difficult circumstances, his native sidein the civil wars, the Scottish side (since Charles I was born in Scotland) he chose.
Perfidious Scot thou this base plot did’st Lay

Perfidious Scota generic Scottish person, or the Scots in general, castigated for treachery (perfidy), thou this base plot As Eardley notes, Charles I surrendered in April 1646 to the Scots, who the next year released him to England’s Parliament, under whose authority he was executed in 1649. did’st lay;
Iſcariot like thou didst thy Kings betray

Iscariot-likeJudas Iscariot, as the disciple who betrayed Jesus Christ to the authorities, became emblematic of treachery. thou didst thy kingsThe plural “kings” suggests that Pulter refers not only to Charles I but to Christ as another monarch betrayed by the Scots. betray.
Hee lost his life but got a lasting &ff;ame
HeCharles I, with echoes of Christ, from the line above lost his life, but got a lasting famereputation; renown;
Thuſs beeing overcome hee overcame
Thus, being overcome, he overcame.
Then Patient bee though things fit not thy Wiſh
Then patient be, though things fit not thy wish;
Thou might’st a been, King, Hart, or &ff;lying &ff;iſh,
Thou might’st have been king, hart, or flying fish.
